'I was so young' Child abuse victim who inspired Coronation Street storyline tells frightening story Lucie was groomed by a paedophile from ages 10 to 16 Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Watch: lady who was sexually groomed at age of 10 speaks out Share this video Get soaps   Thank you for subscribing!   
In Coronation Street , Bethany Platt is set for a shocking grooming storyline at the hands of newcomer Nathan Curtis. 
And a child sex abuse victim who inspired the ITV soap storyline told her horrific story on This Morning - after suffering from ages 10 to 16. 
Speaking to Ruth Langsford in the green room, with her anonymity kept, Lucie said: “We met through social media, he contacted me through there. 
“He befriended me, came down to a child level, spoke about school, games, things I was interested in.” Read More Ruth Langsford spoke to a child sex abuse victim (Photo: ITV) Her story inspired Bethany Platt's Corrie storyline (Photo: ITV) 
She continued: “It was nice to have a friend, I didn’t have many, so it was nice to have someone interested. 
“He told me if anyone found out, they’d be cross with me.” 
Lucy went on to describe how she was “absolutely terrified” when she first met up with him, aged 12. 
She took a friend with her, but he quickly made her leave and they had sex. Read More Lucie explained how she was manipulated by paedophile (Photo: ITV) Ruth handled the interview perfectly (Photo: ITV) 
Lucy said: “People who are abusers are just so scary and manipulate everything you do, how you feel, how you think. 
“They turn it around and make you think you’re not in the wrong. I was so young.” 
She explained how there was police involvement, but it didn’t result in prosecution, which meant “everything he said had come true, and they didn’t believe me”. She gave abuse victims advice (Photo: ITV) 
She then went back to police when she was 15 or 16 years old, and he was imprisoned. 
Giving advice to sex abuse victims, Lucy added: “Just tell somebody you trust. Phone Childline. Tell someone. Even if you’re not convinced it’s abuse. 
“When you’re in the situation, you can’t recognise it’s not OK.”
